hero_dishes.name: Bohemian Potato Pancakes (Brambor√°ky)
hero_dishes.description: Crispy fried potato pancakes loaded with garlic, marjoram, and sometimes bacon - golden brown and served with sour cream or as a side to meat dishes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Peasant food from South Bohemia, these pancakes were a way to stretch ingredients. The secret is grating the potatoes fresh and squeezing out ALL the water, then frying them in lard (never oil). Modern versions are smaller and crispier than the traditional dinner-plate-sized ones

signature_drinks.name: Czech Pilsner Beer
signature_drinks.description: Golden lager beer - Czechia invented pilsner-style beer in 1842, and locals take their beer seriously. Expect a perfect pour with a thick foam head
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in half-liter glasses, always fresh from the tap. Czechs are the world's heaviest beer drinkers per capita. In Czech taverns, the waiter keeps bringing fresh beers until you put a coaster on top of your glass. Never toast - just make eye contact and drink

signature_drinks.name: Becherovka
signature_drinks.description: Bitter herbal liqueur from Karlovy Vary (nearby spa town) - tastes like Christmas spices mixed with medicine. 38% alcohol, bright amber color
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served ice-cold as a digestive after heavy meals. Mix it with tonic water for a 'Beton' (concrete) - the Czech answer to gin and tonic. The recipe is a secret formula of 20+ herbs and spices, known only to two people

food_culture_notes: ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov is a UNESCO World Heritage site with architecture frozen in the medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque periods
The town's name means 'crooked meadow' from Middle High German, referring to the horseshoe bend of the Vltava River
Artist Egon Schiele (student of Gustav Klimt) lived and worked here - his mother was from ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov
Despite being tiny (population 13,000), the town attracts over 2 million tourists per year, creating a bizarre tourist-vs-local food scene
